snippet: The first glimpse of the collection brought astonishment but also anger and the initial stirrings of what will likely be a long battle over who owns the works.
abstract: German authorities describe for first time how trove of missing 20th-century European art, probably confiscated by Nazis, was found during routine tax investigation; give few details of 1,397 works discovered, sparking criticism of government's slow handling of collection; decline to confirm that man suspected of keeping them is Cornelius Gurlitt, son of Hildebrand Gurlitt, who was selected by Nazis to sell such works abroad.

byline.original: By MELISSA EDDY, ALISON SMALE, PATRICIA COHEN and RANDY KENNEDY
byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy reported from Augsburg, Germany; Alison Smale from Berlin; and Patricia Cohen and Randy Kennedy from New York.

lead_paragraph: The first glimpse of the collection brought astonishment but also anger and the initial stirrings of what will likely be a long battle over who owns the works.

headline.main: German Officials Provide Details on Looted Art
headline.print_headline: German Officials Provide Details on Looted Art
